snippet.textDisplay:
Linus, I hope this message reaches you.


My brother from another mother...
Take the empire you've built by exploiting the methods of advertising in it's fullest and turn it upside down to serve you and what your HEART wants to put out now.
You've created the platform and you've worked HARD for it. Whether you got there doing what was RIGHT or not is irrelevant now. Who cares if you promoted consumerism.
You've got peoples attention.
Now teach them the truth.
Even if it's not tech.
Teach them like you would your own children.
We are all brothers and sisters.


-M

snippet.textDisplay:
St. Linus, do you realize how many people you taught how to build their own computers effectively, efficiently, and creatively? You are responsible for modernizing so many lives, careers and families. Your influence is astronomical. There is a person about to get hired on at a big time video game company because you taught that person how to build their own computer and now they have honed their skills and can put them into practice. You have the patience to bestow knowledge unto the masses. You enforce questioning and comparing between different factors. All because it's your passion. You are not doing it for fame and glory you are only doing it because you feel that they should know. If Linus is not the absolute definition of a saint then I don't want to live on this planet anymore.

Personally you've taught me a great many things that college lectures wouldn't come close to. The gift of knowledge is boundless and burdening. Linus built his life from the ground up out of pure passion and joy. Pure is his goal. Just is his cause as he only seeks to enlighten those who would listen and grow in his passion. What man doesn't feel remorse and affliction to mere concepts and details of his future lineage? One who loves. What man frets when his kingdom risks ruin? One who has built. What man expresses empathy toward others not of his flesh? One who knows suffering. What man questions power? One who knows strife. What man desires fame? One who has no milestone.

Linus is a saint, goddammit! Dub him as such! He provides knowledge, very useful knowledge in terms of modern mechanics. This stuff is essential to lives around the world. Governs careers and education. His friends and coworkers have jobs because of Linus, because Linus has a passion for tech. Because Linus sacrifices time he could be spending with his family, he gives it to us. Selflessness in it's purest form. Again I say. Linus isn't doing this for fame and glory. He is doing it to spread awareness and information about anything tech related which our current lives are HEAVILY influenced by. He does this because he loves to help others, because he is being a decent human and I am humbled to have experienced him in my life. His information plays a critical role in so many lives and most don't even realize they are taking it for granted. Thank you. Adieu.

snippet.textDisplay:
You need to do what makes you feel better and complete. It is your life, enjoy it!
But if you leave, LTT and all the other channels will die. Why? Because only you and Luke were the ones who showed real passion about what you do. Luke is already gone. You are thinking about leaving too. What's left on LTT? Those new guys, snobby hipster looking guys who have no charisma, no passion, no emotion, they are here just because it's "cool".
Do what you want and what makes you feel better. But know that once you leave, all these empire will perish.

snippet.textDisplay: To be fair, good for him, he's done for it years. No doubt he's loaded, he's got a family. If he just does cameo roles, that'd be great. He's a SUCCESS and quite frankly, he's bloody made it.I remember first watching the NCIX and Linus videos 10 years ago, deciding to buy a HD5770 and AMD athlon 2, in 2010, I bought my first computer with my own money that I saved for for through hard work instead of using the old family computers I would inherit, and Linus was a big part of that process. 10 years on, I'm here, and Linus has 10 mil subscribers and I couldn't be happier to have witness this pan out.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yeah, I used to pick up abandoned/Grown out computers and such, from the dump,fix them up then sell them on Ebay but $9 smart phones, $29 tablets and free with service subscription along with E-waste laws in Hawaii directing the electroncss to Paradise Recycling forced me into retirement

This modern disposable computer/cell phone era kinda remind me of the Timex Sinclair,dial up netbooks, and pocket netbooks requiring dial up in the 80's that failed pre WiFi/bliutootn in 80's (got a Casio eBook reader/email reader somewhere in my e-junk drawer...like a modern smartphone orvSwitch GUI interface)

Yeah, "Associates" vs "Friends" is usually semantics if you are close knit....associates can be friends

Well, honest modesty in what you do is a sign of true greatness. ....I still remember my first computer gifted to me by a Hero figure (a Tandy TL/1 286 which got lost during repair so Radio Shack replaced it with a TL/2 386 and during another repair was lost and Radio Shack replaced it with a Tandy 1000 486 VGA😸)...lasted from 1991 to 2011 and could have lasted longer if I hadn't botched modifying the battery
snippet.textOriginal:
Yeah, I used to pick up abandoned/Grown out computers and such, from the dump,fix them up then sell them on Ebay but  $9 smart phones, $29 tablets and free with service subscription along with E-waste laws in Hawaii directing  the electroncss to Paradise Recycling forced me into retirement

This modern disposable computer/cell phone era kinda remind me of the Timex Sinclair,dial up netbooks, and pocket netbooks requiring dial up in the 80's that failed pre WiFi/bliutootn in 80's (got a Casio eBook reader/email reader somewhere in my e-junk drawer...like a modern smartphone orvSwitch GUI interface)

Yeah, "Associates" vs "Friends" is usually semantics if you are close knit....associates can be friends

snippet.textDisplay: Extraordinarily impressive. I salute you Linus. So much of what you said resonated. I am from the Lower Mainland and I think the same age as yourself. I too have had a very sad experience in my life and I just want to say how deeply I understand the feelings in your video.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dude, you are brave for bearing yourself like this for Millions. Kudos.



On the topic of "When is enough, enough?" When you know inside that something is out of balance. It's past time to change things up when you're at the point you are.



I went through this when I had my daughter 2 years ago, I think all your fans will support you stepping back. The ones who don't haven't been through this and they will never understand.


You do you man, nothing is worth living a life you aren't happy with.

snippet.textDisplay:
LINUS PLEASE READ! first off let me say congrats and well done. You've worked hard to where you got and thats no small feat. Now then as someone who retired young and recently (Q4 2017 if you're wondering and 30 years young) let me give you a piece of advice, retiring SUCKS. True I spent a few weeks traveling the world. spend 3 months in the PH, then that got boring, Went to japan, That got boring, Went to South Korea, That got boring, went on a few cruises I can list the things I did in a whole essay but im not going to bore you with the details Point is .. retirement is BORING. Sure it sounds great. be all "yay no more work" but then what? As for me I ended up getting completely bored after a year and a half. You have all this energy that will bottle up within you and one day you'll wake up and be stir crazy and want to do something else.


So what did I do? .. I built a small real estate company. Honestly I just bought appartments and rent them out to allow me to keep this life but more importantly It allows me to remain mentally busy. Gives me things to fill my time. and that;s the important thing to do. Finding things to fill your time.


You want to retire, thats great. go for it. DO IT. go to the beach with those socks and sandals you love to wear. Sport them and live it up. We've been here for you since you started, we'll be here when you return. Even if you only do half the content and go part time, even a quarter of the time. its better than retiring cold turkey and then waking up one morning and be all. great now what. Trust me I was there


Now remember, this is me, im a nobody in this world, just a girl with a Falcon x8 a nice house in the islands of the PH, and I spend half my time at the beach and half the time doing work. I just wanted to impart some of my experiences to attempt to help you out. No you didnt ask for it but I just dont want to see someone like me make the same mistakes I did.

snippet.textDisplay:
You can never estimate the extent to which you affected the world. But if you are honest with yourself you know you were the reason some kid went to college doing tech. Maybe more than one. Maybe one of those kids grows up and builds/maintains/repairs a server that will crunch the numbers to cure cancer. Maybe not. But it is few kids more than without you. That's all you can hope for when future is unknown - creating positive change. Your forums create and aggregate knowledge, your videos inspire, inform and entertain people, some of which are in a very bad place and find refuge in it. You can never know it, but you can only hope that you do. I'm sure you know that it does. They don't cure cancer. Neither do you. But your work makes it that much more possible for that to happen because you are one of the best at it.
At the same time lack of inspiration is a real thing. You gotta step back and find it again. Doesn't matter where, you got the knowhow to make something out of it.
Yeah

snippet.textDisplay:
Inspiring millions of people and becoming a corner stone in the tech review industry is no short feat, I'll tell you that.
However, if I've learned anything from my time here on this earth. It's that we shape our own realities. No amount of time, effort, money, or margin is going to convince you that you're happy with what it is you're doing.

You really have to sit back and decide what it is that you want. Dig deep into what it is that bothers you, and make decisions based on a confluence of logic and heart to meet your desired result.
Step away from the script. Hire a writer; be with your kids. Find a middle ground if that's what is calling you. Reality is what you make of it. Happiness is a construct of your making. Much like LTT is.
snippet.textOriginal:
Inspiring millions of people and becoming a corner stone in the tech review industry is no short feat, I'll tell you that. 
However, if I've learned anything from my time here on this earth. It's that we shape our own realities. No amount of time, effort, money, or margin is going to convince you that you're happy with what it is you're doing. 

You really have to sit back and decide what it is that you want. Dig deep into what it is that bothers you, and make decisions based on a confluence of logic and heart to meet your desired result. 
Step away from the script. Hire a writer; be with your kids. Find a middle ground if that's what is calling you. Reality is what you make of it. Happiness is a construct of your making. Much like LTT is.

snippet.textDisplay: Linus if you read this i hope this makes you feel a little better about your impact on consumerism, i have never had much money and i hate to let old tech go to waste, ive always sat down and watched your videos and seen all this cool flashy hardware i could never hope to afford, but i saw scrapyard was and figured that instead of buying a bunch of brand new low end hardware at a price i could hardly afford i could buy used hardwarez give it a new use, and have a better performing computer at a price i could actually afford, it was the absolute biggest improvement i could ever hope for going from i believe a gt 620 to a gtx 750, it was a bad choice for the price i believe, but it set me on the path to building whole systems this way, i made money building computers this way, it was amazing when i built a system with a gtx 1080, the card i had been eyeballing for 4 years and slotted it into the computer and watched it fire up, i got it for an amazing price, and i believe i have helped around a dozen kids get a computer at a better peice than the prebuilt stuff, that performs well, and re-uses parts that would likely wind up in the garbage, and i have managed to build my knowledge in tech and get actually nice things and its all thanks to you, working with tech is a rather good pastime for me as well, you set me on this path because everything else i looked up for computers was boring, you got me hooked, and i mean if not for having this hobby there were times when my depression hit so bad if i didnt have this to distract me id have probably killed myself, not a fun topic but i just want you to realize that your channel doesn't just promote mindless consumerism, its done a lot of good for a lot of people and i at least wouldn't be where i am today without you

snippet.textDisplay: Every time this video pops up in my recommended. I can't bring myself to watch. Just jumped on this comment thread to say you helped spark my love for computers and technology in high school. And in May I'm going to graduate with a degree in Computer Science. I'm typing this on the computer I built with your videos. Godspeed with whatever you do Linus. I'll miss you but I want you to be happy.

snippet.textDisplay: No-one likes quitters
snippet.textOriginal: No-one likes quitters

snippet.textDisplay: Click bait....
snippet.textOriginal: Click bait....

snippet.textDisplay: Linus, we love you. You have brought joy, laughter, knowledge and distraction from the day to day mundanity of reality to literally millions of people on a daily basis. I wouldn't have built the PC that I have now if your videos hadn't inspired me to do so. You and your team work so hard to bring joy to other people. Wherever you go and whatever you do, do it in the knowledge that you have the support of the masses. You've made us happy. Now make you happy.
